title: Show HN: Tiny LLMs – Browser-based private AI models for a wide array of tasks
summary: Tiny LLMs offers browser-based AI models for various tasks, prioritizing efficiency, user-friendliness, and privacy. Services include speech recognition, text to speech, image enhancement, image reading, and text to video. Other tools include a media converter, photo filter, and YouTube summary.

title: Show HN: I made a really silly personal landing page
summary: This content appears to be a list of social media and professional networking platforms where an individual named David Adler has profiles. These platforms include GitHub, LinkedIn, StackOverflow, Twitter, Instagram, and Hacker News.

title: The real realtime preemption end game
summary: The addition of realtime support to Linux, which started in 2004, is nearing completion, according to Thomas Gleixner, who spoke at the 2023 Linux Plumbers Conference. The aim of realtime preemption is to ensure that the highest-priority process can run with minimal and predictable delay. The only major issue left to be solved is with printk(), a function for sending messages to system consoles and logs. The function is currently fully synchronous, which introduces latency and contradicts the goals of the realtime work. Efforts to fix the printk() problem have been ongoing since 2018, with three final patch sets currently being developed.

title: Moving from AWS to Bare-Metal saved us 230k$ /yr
summary: The article discusses how a company saved $230,000 per year by moving its infrastructure from Amazon Web Services (AWS) to a bare-metal solution. The transition gave the company more control over their resources and improved service reliability and customer communication. Initially, the company used a Kubernetes cluster on AWS for their open-source observability platform, OneUptime. However, they realized the benefits of AWS could be achieved at a lower cost elsewhere. The company then decided to run a Microk8s cluster in a colocation facility, which gave them dedicated resources and eliminated the 'noisy neighbor' issue often experienced in shared hosting environments. The move to bare-metal servers allowed them to customize their infrastructure to meet their specific needs.

title: Migrating to OpenTelemetry
summary: Airplane has been working to migrate its observability data generation and collection to the OpenTelemetry (OTel) standard. OpenTelemetry is a set of standards and tools for processing observability data including logs, metrics, and traces. The benefits of OTel include vendor agnosticism, unified data types, and solid library support for common programming languages. Prior to the migration, Airplane collected data from its own systems, customer-hosted infrastructure, and customer browsers, using several vendors including Datadog, Honeycomb, and Google Cloud Logging. The migration to OTel has improved data collection reliability, vendor connectivity, and cost monitoring and control.

title: From email to phone number, a new OSINT approach (2019)
summary: A new approach to Open Source Intelligence (OSINT) has been discovered, allowing for the potential exposure of phone numbers through the password reset process on various websites. By entering an email address, a hacker can initiate the password reset process and gain access to several digits of the phone number associated with that account. The number of digits exposed varies from site to site, with some showing the last four digits, others the first one and last two, etc. This could potentially allow a hacker to guess a full phone number by combining the digits exposed on various websites.

title: Emu Video and Emu Edit, our latest generative AI research milestones
summary: Meta has introduced Emu Video and Emu Edit, two new developments in generative AI research. Emu Video uses a simple method for text-to-video generation based on diffusion models, and can respond to a variety of inputs such as text only, image only, and both text and image. It is efficient and can generate high-resolution videos. Emu Edit is a novel approach to image editing, offering precise control and enhanced capabilities. It can perform tasks such as local and global editing, removing and adding a background, color and geometry transformations, detection and segmentation, and more. Both tools are part of Meta's ongoing work in the field of generative AI.

title: OCapN, Interoperable Capabilities over the Network
summary: The Spritely Institute has introduced OCapN (Object Capability Network), a protocol designed to provide support for secure, distributed, and seamless communication for networked applications. Initially developed as part of the Goblins distributed object programming environment, OCapN has been expanded beyond Goblins thanks to a grant from NLnet. The protocol simplifies the building of peer-to-peer systems and features intuitive distributed programming, object capability security, promise pipelining, distributed garbage collection, and certificate-based third-party handoffs. Jessica Tallon, who has been working with Spritely on an NLnet grant-funded initiative, has been focusing on improving OCapN support in Goblins implementations and initiating the standardization push for OCapN.

title: Zimbra 0-day used to steal email data from government organizations
summary: Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) discovered a 0-day exploit targeting Zimbra Collaboration, an email server used by many organizations, in June 2023. The exploit was used to steal email data, user credentials, and authentication tokens. Four different groups were observed exploiting the bug, with most activity occurring after the initial fix was made public on Github. Zimbra patched the vulnerability in July 2023. However, three groups began exploiting the vulnerability after the hotfix was made public, emphasizing the importance of applying fixes promptly. The initial discovery of the 0-day vulnerability was a campaign targeting a government organization in Greece. Other campaigns targeted government organizations in Moldova and Tunisia. TAG recommends keeping software fully updated and applying security updates as soon as they become available.

title: Sweden Gov Announces 'Massive Expansion' of Nuclear Energy
Why thinking hard makes us feel tired
summary: A desire to rest after mentally demanding work is a physiological response, according to a study. The study suggests that difficult tasks lead to a build-up of a signalling molecule in the brain, which triggers fatigue. This finding links mental fatigue to changes in brain metabolism.

title: std::source_location Is Broken
summary: The article discusses the limitations of std::source_location in C++20 compared to the older __FILE__ macro. The author explains that while std::source_location can potentially eliminate the need for macros, it does not work for their specific needs in embedded systems, where strings must be modeled as types and their size known at compile time. The author concludes that until a new mechanism is developed, they will continue to use the __FILE__ macro, despite its downsides. The irony is that std::source_location provides information known only at compile time, but its current specification and implementation do not allow full utilization of that information at compile time.

title: You don't need a CRDT to build a collaborative experience
summary: The article discusses the use of Conflict-free Replicated Data Types (CRDTs) in creating collaborative experiences. While CRDTs are useful for offline-first applications and text editing due to their ability to avoid overwriting changes and handle high rates of edits, they also have drawbacks. These include an ever-growing state due to the need to record both existing and deleted data, complex implementations which often lock users into specific technologies, and an opaque state which can be difficult to inspect or store. The author suggests alternatives to CRDTs for collaboration, such as contextual information, locking for safety, small-scale updates, and real-time fan-out of updates.

title: A floating solar-powered device produces clean water and clean fuel
summary: Researchers at the University of Cambridge have developed a solar-powered device that can convert contaminated water or seawater into clean hydrogen fuel and purified water. The device, which is inspired by photosynthesis, can operate from polluted or seawater sources and produce clean drinking water simultaneously. The device uses a nanostructured carbon mesh to create water vapour for hydrogen production, while the rest of the light in the solar spectrum is used to vaporise the water. This innovation could be beneficial in resource-limited or off-grid environments and could help address the energy and water crises in many parts of the world.

title: Federated finetuning of Whisper on Raspberry Pi 5
summary: The blog post introduces a code example that uses OpenAI's Whisper, a state-of-the-art ASR model, and fine-tunes it for keyword spotting in a federated manner. The process involves designing a Federated Learning pipeline with Flower for keyword spotting classification using a pre-trained Whisper encoder. The model classifies 1-second audio waveforms into one of twelve possible classes. The example also benchmarks the new Raspberry Pi 5, showing superior performance across tasks compared to the previous Raspberry Pi 4. The keyword spotting model can classify unseen keywords with an accuracy of over 97% after a few rounds of training.

title: Privacy is priceless, but Signal is expensive
summary: Signal, the world’s most widely used private messaging app, is a nonprofit that is powered by donations and does not monetize user data. The app uses end-to-end encryption technology, the Signal Protocol, to protect billions of conversations on platforms like WhatsApp and Google Messages. Signal is also working on adding quantum resistance to its protocol and has developed metadata protection technologies to secure personal details. The app's nonprofit status ensures it remains focused on privacy and is not pressured to sacrifice privacy for profit. However, being a nonprofit does not lessen Signal's operating costs. It currently spends millions of dollars annually and estimates it will need around $50 million a year to operate by 2025.

title: Planning for Unplanned Work in Linear
summary: This blog post discusses strategies for managing unplanned work in the product building process. The author explains that while planned work is scheduled and organized, unplanned work, such as bug reports or feature requests, can appear randomly. The post emphasizes the importance of preparing for such unexpected tasks and outlines the challenges associated with them. Unplanned work is divided into two phases: intake and execution, each with its own unique challenges. The intake phase involves the reporting of unplanned work, which can be difficult due to the various channels through which issues can be reported. The execution phase involves resolving these reported issues, which can be complicated due to unclear responsibilities and priorities. The author further discusses the importance of a smooth intake process, suggesting it allows for better tracking and management of issues.

title: AI-Exploits: Repo of multiple unauthenticated RCEs in AI tools
summary: AI security firm Protect AI has released a repository, ai-exploits, to help the Information Security community understand practical attacks against AI/Machine Learning infrastructure. The repository is a collection of exploits and scanning templates for responsibly disclosed vulnerabilities affecting machine learning tools. Protect AI's research shows that many attacks against AI tools, libraries, and frameworks can lead to complete system takeovers or loss of sensitive data, models, or credentials, often without the need for authentication. The company hopes to raise awareness about the amount of vulnerable components that currently exist in the AI/ML ecosystem.

title: Frutiger Aero
summary: Frutiger Aero, also known as Web 2.0 Gloss, is a design style that was popular in advertising, media, stock imagery, and technology from 2004 to 2013. It is characterized by skeuomorphism, glossy textures, cloudy skies, tropical fish, water, bubbles, glass, lens flare, sprawling patterns, "humanism", aero glass, bokeh, Frutiger fonts, abstract tech, auroras, and bright, vibrant colors. The term "Frutiger Aero" was coined in 2017 by Sofi Lee of the Consumer Aesthetics Research Institute and gained popularity in 2022. The aesthetic is named after Adrian Frutiger, who created the Frutiger fonts commonly used in this design style, and Windows Aero, a UI theme that influenced many design choices during that era.

title: Microsoft support 'cracks' Windows for customer after activation fails
The CWEB System of Structured Documentation
summary: "The CWEB System of Structured Documentation" is a book by Donald E. Knuth and Silvio Levy, which serves as the definitive user's guide and reference manual for the CWEB system. CWEB is a software system that allows for the creation of readable programs, superior documentation, reduced debugging time, and easy program maintenance. It views a program as a communication to humans rather than instructions for a computer. CWEB is a version of WEB, originally developed by Knuth, for documenting C, C++, and Java programs. The book also includes an open letter by Knuth to the U.S. Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks. The CWEB software is freely available for download.

title: Operating on a minimal two-core Postgres instance: Query optimization insights
summary: The author discusses how their data team has managed to operate an energy trading company's infrastructure using only two PostgreSQL database instances, each with two CPU cores and four GB of RAM. Despite the minimal resources, the company has maintained satisfactory performance. This was achieved by balancing costs arising from short-term performance degradation, developer hours needed for countermeasures, and costs for scaling up database resources. In a five-part article series, the author plans to show how common performance bottlenecks can be eliminated through query optimization, index tuning, partitioning, database server tuning, and the use of read-only replicas. The first part focuses on identifying inefficient queries through monitoring.

title: Hackers know everything is securities fraud
summary: The content is a security message from Bloomberg, indicating unusual activity detected from the user's computer network. It asks the user to confirm they are not a robot to continue using the site. It also advises the user to ensure their browser supports JavaScript and cookies and that they are not blocking them. The user is directed to Bloomberg's Terms of Service and Cookie Policy for more information. For further assistance, the user can contact Bloomberg's support team.

title: Hello World on the GPU (2019)
summary: This tutorial explains how to create a "Hello World" program using graphics processing unit (GPU) programming. It involves working with pixels directly to draw text to the console. The tutorial goes through the steps of defining an alphabet, encoding a message from this alphabet, assembling the text into positioned text, loading the font as glyphs, and then printing it pixel-by-pixel to the top of the console, a process known as 'rasterizing'. The tutorial also explains how to set up the console instance, adapter, and window to display the text.

title: Hyundai to Be First Automaker to Sell New Cars on Amazon
Smart drugs reduce quality of effort, and slow decision-making
summary: A new study conducted by the University of Melbourne found that 'smart drugs', used by many students as cognitive enhancers, actually reduce the quality of effort and increase the time taken to complete a decision-making task in cognitively healthy people. The study involved 40 healthy participants aged 18-35, who were given a problem-solving task known as the 'knapsack optimisation problem'. Each participant was given a different identical-looking white pill containing either a dose of Ritalin, modafinil, dextroamphetamine or a placebo. The results showed that the drugs did not affect the chance of a participant finding the solution, but participants tended to perform worse after taking one of the drugs, and spent substantially more time working on their solution. The drugs also increased the number of times the participants moved items in and out of the knapsack, but did not increase 'effort quality' or productivity.

title: A failed AI girlfriend product, and my lessons
summary: The author developed an AI friend product, Dolores, inspired by the GPT-4 capabilities and the Stanford’s Western Town paper. Dolores is an iOS app that provides a template character setting, allowing users to chat with different characters. The author initially designed it to be consistent with the original Stanford paper, but this resulted in long response times and dialogues. To fix this, he reduced the frequency of reflection and the length of dialogue memory. The app was launched without sufficient testing due to high daily API costs. The author discovered that users demand realistic voices and that AI friend products have long usage times. Despite the high cost of realistic voice synthesis, 70% of Dolores' users in June chose this option.

title: Printed robots with bones, ligaments, and tendons
I think I need to go lie down
summary: The content indicates that JavaScript is disabled in the user's browser, preventing them from using twitter.com. The user is advised to enable JavaScript or switch to a supported browser. There's also a mention of a problem that occurred, but the user is encouraged to try again. It also mentions the availability of a list of supported browsers in the Help Center. The page includes links to the Help Center, Terms of Service, Privacy Policy, Cookie Policy, Imprint, and Ads info. The copyright is held by X Corp, 2023.
